te:
>
> Dear Kitsuno,

> Thank you for your reply.  I can't believe how p=
henomenally 
> difficult it is to piece together all this information...  C=
learly, 
> record-keeping was not a priority for Samurai or Peasants during=
 the 
> turbulent 1620's...  
> 
> Can you recommend any well-organized boo=
ks, periodicals, and/or 
> websites that provides comprehensive lists of Da=
imyos per regions?  
> i.e. I am looking for a list Daimyos on Kyushu only.=
  

Record-keeping has always been an obsession throughout Japanese
history=
. Every clan has detailed genealogies and detailed clan
histories. If you c=
an't read Japanese, you are more limited, but I'd
just be creative - I woul=
d first find a map something like this one:
http://www.samurai-archives.com=
/maphome.html
Then I would write down the names of all of the daimyo I see =
on
Kyushu, and then I would get various library books that deal with
Japane=
se history, flip to the index, and try to find out who was in
charge of the=
 clan during the 1620s - off the top of my head, George
Sansom's 2nd and/or=
 3rd book (History of Japan) would be one place to
look. It's pretty basic =
research. If you read Japanese, the Japanese
wikipedia and harimaya.com has=
 detailed family trees for almost every
major clan, and the Sengoku Jinmei =
Jiten edited by Abe would be
another resource. I'd help out, but I don't ha=
ve the time. Maybe
someone else around here?

Also, I'm curious - what "tur=
bulence" are you talking about during the
1620s? I can't think of much of a=
nything overly turbulent happening in
the 1620s aside from the non-event of=
 Iemitsu becoming shogun, and the
start of Sakoku.
